title: R43557
content: The first section of this report outlines the FY2015 legislative branch appropriations process, including the initial request submission, hearings, markups, and passage of H.R. 4487. It also covers the enactment of continuing appropriations resolutions and the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015. The FY2015 legislative branch appropriations process included the enactment of various acts (P.L. 113-164, P.L. 113-203, P.L. 113-235) and the submission of a budget request for $4.471 billion in new authority. The report details funding levels for FY2014 and FY2015, as well as legislative branch agencies and entities. The FY2015 U.S. Budget requested $4.471 billion for legislative branch activities. Hearings were held in 2014, with the House subcommittee marking up the bill on April 4, 2014. The full House Appropriations Committee then considered the bill, with one amendment proposed for a housing stipend of $25 per day. On April 9, 2014, the House Appropriations Committee held a markup of the FY2015 bill. Representative Moran proposed a $25 per day housing stipend for Members living 50 or more miles away from DC, which failed. The House considered H.R. 4487 on May 1, 2014, with amendments including one by Representative Nugent to prohibit MRA funding for vehicle leasing (failed 196-221) and one by Representative Speier for $500,000 for sexual harassment training. The House Appropriations Committee held a markup of the FY2015 bill. Representative Moran proposed a housing stipend for Members living 50 or more miles away from DC, which failed. Amendments included one to prohibit MRA funding for vehicle leasing (failed 196-221) and one for $500,000 for sexual harassment training. Another amendment reduced funding for the Botanic Garden and transferred funds to the spending reduction account. An amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center failed, as did an amendment to defund the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund. The House Appropriations Committee held a markup of the FY2015 bill. Representative Moran proposed a housing stipend for Members living 50 or more miles away from DC, which failed. Amendments included one to prohibit MRA funding for vehicle leasing (failed 196-221) and one for $500,000 for sexual harassment training. Another amendment reduced funding for the Botanic Garden and transferred funds to the spending reduction account. An amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center by $243,000 failed by a vote of 207-212, while an amendment to defund the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund also failed. Representative Hall's amendment to prohibit funds from being used to deliver printed copies of the Statement of Disbursements of the House to any Member of the House was agreed to by voice vote, as was Representative Wenstrup's amendment to prohibit funding for the delivery of printed copies of the House daily calendar to any Member of the House. Representative Holt's amendment to appropriate $2.5 million to reinstitute the Office of Technology Assessment, offset from funds in the House Historic Buildings Revitalization Trust Fund, failed by a vote of 164-248. The House passed H.R. 4487 by a vote of 402-14, but an amendment to appropriate $2.5 million for the Office of Technology Assessment failed. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered the bill but took no further action before the start of FY2015. Funding for the legislative branch was provided through continuing resolutions until the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015, which allocated $4.3 billion for legislative branch operations. The FY2015 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act provided $4.3 billion for legislative branch operations, an increase of 1.0% from FY2014. A funding gap in FY2014 led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days until a CR was enacted. Funding for FY2014 was eventually provided through a consolidated appropriations bill. Following a temporary continuing resolution on January 15, 2014, a consolidated appropriations bill was enacted on January 17, providing $4.259 billion for the legislative branch for FY2014. This funding was in addition to the FY2013 funding provided by a previous bill. The new budget authority aimed to stay within the FY2013 discretionary spending limits. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act, as amended by the Budget Control Act of 2011 and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012, set spending limits. After the enactment of P.L. 113-6, OMB calculated additional rescissions for security and nonsecurity budget authority. Sequestration reductions implemented on March 1 reduced legislative branch accounts by 5.0%. Division G of the FY2012 Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $4.307 billion for the legislative branch, $236.9 million below the FY2011 level. The legislative branch budget was reduced to $4.307 billion in FY2012, a decrease from previous years. Funding levels have remained below FY2004 levels in constant dollars. Additional funding was allocated for specific agencies like the Government Accountability Office and Capitol Police. The legislative branch budget in constant dollars remains below the FY2004 level. The Senate requested $907.2 million for FY2015, with an increase of 5.6% over FY2014. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $865.9 million, a 0.8% increase. The FY2015 act provides $864.3 million, a 0.6% increase. Additional information on the Senate account is presented in Table 5. Appropriations for Senate committees are contained in two accounts, with the inquiries and investigations account requesting $134.0 million. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $133.3 million, and the FY2015 act provided $15.1 million for the Committee on Appropriations account. The Senators' Official Personnel and Office Expense Account (SOPOEA) provides funds for each Senator's office expenses. The Senators' Official Personnel and Office Expense Account (SOPOEA) provides funds for each Senator's office expenses, including administrative and clerical assistance, legislative assistance, and official office expenses. The Senate requested $429.7 million for FY2015, but the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended and the FY2015 act provided $390.0 million, the same as FY2014. In contrast, the House requested $1.20 billion for FY2015, an increase of 1.7%, but the House-passed FY2015 level of $1.18 billion remained the same as FY2014. Funding for House committees is under the "committee employees" appropriation heading. The House of Representatives account for FY2015 requested $126.3 million for committee employees, with $23.7 million allocated for the Committee on Appropriations. The Members' Representational Allowance (MRA) supports Members in their official duties. Funding levels remained the same as FY2014 for both subheadings. The House requested $23.7 million (+2.0%) for FY2015, the same level as the FY2014 act. The Members' Representational Allowance (MRA) was $565.4 million (+2.0%), consistent with FY2014. The U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) requested $355.7 million for FY2015, an increase of 5.1% from FY2014. The House-passed bill provided $348.0 million (+2.8%), while the Senate-reported version allocated $344.0 million (+1.7%). The House-passed level was included in the FY2015 act. The U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) received $355.7 million for FY2015, a 5.1% increase from FY2014. The House-passed bill proposed $348.0 million, while the Senate-reported version suggested $344.0 million. The FY2015 act maintained the House-passed funding level. Appropriations for the USCP cover salaries, overtime pay, benefits, vehicle expenses, security equipment, training programs, and more. The Capitol Police requested $291.4 million for salaries, an increase of 4.4% from the previous year. They also requested $64.3 million for general expenses, an increase of 8.1%. The House-passed bill would have provided $286.5 million for salaries and $61.5 million for general expenses. The Capitol Police requested $284.6 million for salaries and general expenses, with an increase of 2.0%. The House-passed bill provided the FY2015 level. Another appropriation for Capitol Police buildings and grounds was requested at $25.6 million, an increase of 32.3%. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $20.7 million for this purpose. The FY2015 budget for Capitol Police was $19.2 million, with discussions on training requests, radio modernization, incidents involving USCP, overtime use, and discrimination complaints. The Senate subcommittee also discussed incidents involving USCP and increased access with funding returning to pre-sequestration levels. The Office of Compliance enforces the Congressional Accountability Act, applying employment and workplace safety laws to Congress and certain legislative branch entities. The Architect of the Capitol (AOC) is responsible for the maintenance, operation, development, and preservation of the U.S. Capitol Complex, including various buildings and grounds. Operations of the Architect are funded through 10 accounts. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for the maintenance, operation, development, and preservation of the U.S. Capitol Complex. The FY2015 bill for the Architect of the Capitol included provisions on the use of scrims during construction projects and educational outreach efforts. Discussions at hearings focused on funding for the Capitol Dome rehabilitation project, project prioritization, and plans for the renovation of the Cannon House Office Building. The Library of Congress serves as both Congress's parliamentary library and the de facto national library. The Library of Congress serves as Congress's parliamentary and national library, with services including acquisition, maintenance, preservation of a collection of over 158 million items, administration of copyright laws, and providing reading material to the blind. It also offers legal research services and public policy analysis to Congress. The Library of Congress provides services to Congress, including legal research, law-related services, public policy research, analysis, and legislative assistance. The Open World Leadership Center supports democratic changes by inviting foreign leaders to observe democracy in the US. The Open World Leadership Center, established in 2000 at the Library of Congress, promotes democratic changes by inviting foreign leaders to observe the US government and society. The program expanded in 2003 to include additional countries and received funding requests for FY2015. The House-passed bill proposed a reduction in funding, which was discussed during the subcommittee markup.
